summary: This Court of Appeal decision in Osei Yeboah v. Bonte Goldmines Limited (CA No. 82/99, 10 February 2000) centered on a land dispute involving a farmer's claim for trespass and compensation after the mining company destroyed 4,000 teak trees on his land. The trial court dismissed the trespass claim, recognizing the company's legal mining rights under PNDCL 153, but awarded GHS 2.6 million in compensation. On appeal, the key issue was whether the Land Valuation Board had exclusive authority to determine compensation under Section 71 of PNDCL 153. The appellate court held that the statute does not oust judicial jurisdiction, especially where the Board compromised its impartiality by advising the company against paying compensation, thereby rendering it unable to mediate fairly. The court affirmed the trial court's award, emphasizing that natural justice required judicial intervention when statutory mechanisms fail due to bias or procedural breakdown.
citations: Republic v. Military Tribunal Ex Parte Ofosu-Amaah 1973 GLR 227
Republic v. Special Tribunal Ex-Parte Forson 1980-2 GLR 529
rationaleHighlights: Section 71 of PNDCL 153 does not contain clear ouster language and thus does not exclude court jurisdiction.
The Land Valuation Board lost impartiality by advising the mining company against compensation, breaching natural justice.
Courts may intervene when statutory compensation mechanisms fail due to bias or procedural unfairness.
The trial court properly exercised jurisdiction in awarding compensation where agreement was impossible.
Evidence of teak tree ownership was sufficiently established despite lack of receipts, per Yanusah v. Habena.
